texts.shortText: Forms attractive fairly stiff fan-like branching plants arranged all in one plane. Axes segmented and main branches occur at intervals of about 6-20 segments, diverging at a fairly wide angle to form an open lattice. There are rows of tiny branchlets along the main axes between the main branches. Tips of branches strongly tapering and not distinctly incurved. Colour reddish-brown.
Reaches about 200 mm on west coast, but much smaller on south coast. Main branches less than 1 mm wide.

Global: Namibia and South Africa, also reported from Brazil.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Durban.
May be attached to rocks, but often epiphytic of other algae. Common in low intertidal pools and on sublittoral fringe.
Reproductive structures on small branchlets along main axes.

Several other similar regional species in this and closely-related genera â€“ see Stegenga reference for a more detailed account of and identification key to west coast species. This species a mainly identified by the flat, fan-like shape, branching pattern and rows of small branchlets along main axes.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Barros-Barreto, MB, Jaramillo, MA, Hommersand, MH, Ferreira, PCG & Maggs, CA (2023). Phylogenetic analysis of the red algal tribe Ceramieae reveals multiple morphological homoplasies but defines new genera. Cryptogamie, Algologie, 44(2), 13-33.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 412 as Ceramium obsoletum).

Simons, RH (1966). The genus Ceramium in South Africa. Bothalia, 9, 153-168.

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 419 as Ceramium obsoletum).
